title: When writing a novel, do you start with the characters or the plot? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. When writing a novel, do you start with the characters or the plot? It depends. If you get an opportunity to write a Power Rangers story(not fanfiction) ( I am picking Power Rangers randomly because I never have and suspect I never will), do you start by thinking about characters or plot? You may think you are starting about characters, because that’s what you know you are going to write, but chances are you are starting with plot, trying to find something interesting for those characters to do that hasn’t already been done. Or are you? Did you start with the idea that the story would be about the Yellow Ranger because he’s your favorite? Then maybe you started with characters. Personally, when not writing a media tie-in (yes I have, no, it wasn’t fan fiction), I tend to start with neither plot not character. I start with REALLY COOL IDEA. Then I see if I can make a plot out of it. Or, sometimes, I wonder what kind of character would be in the middle of that REALLY COOL IDEA and that will help me create plot based upon what that character will do. Those usually turn out pretty well. It’s kind of like starting in the middle and working backward and forward until the story is done. I have started with what I thought was REALLY COOL CHARACTER. That didn’t work out so well. Not horrible, mind you, but, meh. I may revisit someday if I get a really good idea/plot idea for that character again. I may not. I have started out with REALLY COOL PLOT. More than once. Those worked out better, but, again, meh. Forcing characters into plots causes problems. They don’t want to follow the script you’ve lain out for them, they get REALLY COOL IDEAS of their own and try to do that instead. Then the plot starts to feel “shoehorned” into place. All in all, I don’t think there is a “wrong” way to do it, there are just ways that work better for some people. I hope that helps!

Aristotle said to start with plot, and let that dictate character. Lejos Egri said to start with character and let that dictate plot. Thomas McCormack, in The Fiction Editor, points out that writers actually start out in all kinds of different ways. He gives plenty of examples of writers that you know and admire starting in wildly different ways. In the movie Rounders, Matt Damon’s reads cards well enough that he can tell everyone at the poker table what they’re holding. That fascinated me, but the movie didn’t explain how he did it. So I decided to write a story in which someone—someone smarter than me—does that. If I write the story, explaining how the character does it, then I’ll know myself how it’s done, right? So that’s how I started that story, neither plot nor character, but situation, a single plot point in a larger story. Then I created this plot where a woman’s husband gambles away their mortgage payment, so she has to learn to play poker and manipulate her way into a men-only game, and win back the money her husband lost. She’s really mad at him. So then I created the woman. Who can she be? How stable is the marriage? Will she stay with her husband after he’s been this irresponsible? Will she instead go with her husband’s boss, the guy who made him play poker and then bankrupted him because he didn’t have a poker face? Or will she go back to her old college boyfriend who wants her back? What kind of woman can be torn in this way? What’s her backstory? Who is her confidant, the person she tells her secrets to, so that the readers can know what she’s thinking without an omniscient narrator? What history makes her so forthcoming with that person? And who else is in the game? What are they thinking? How does she know what they’re holding? Then the big surprise. They say, “No surprise for the author, no surprise for the reader.” In the big hand, the climax, when she’s raised the stakes so much that if she loses, she and her husband will have no house, no car, no money, no valuables. They will be flat broke. She glances at her husband and sees that he trusts and admires her. She’s been angry at him for risking too much on a poker game, but he absolutely trusts that she’s doing the right thing when she does that. She forgives her husband, right in the middle of the critical hand. The story, see, wasn’t really supposed to be about that. But it turned out to be so important that I didn’t even finish playing out the hand. I jumped to the final scene, where the players show up at her house, which she and her husband still live in, so she must have won the big hand. All of which means that I had to go back and develop the anger plot. When did she get angry? What is the changing texture of the anger? If the climax is when she gives up her anger, then all the other major plot points have to be about that too. In the next draft, it has to be a whole new story. Which means that maybe I don’t put in a lot about how she reads people’s cards. And that’s okay, according to Anne Lamont (Bird by Bird). She says that when your story is done, you are supposed to take out the original seed that it grew from—but which no longer fits as part of the story—and put it back in your toolbox so you can use it again. That seed, she says, is your life’s work. All of which is just to illustrate that you can start any way you want, as long as you start. By the time you’re ready for the second draft, it may be a whole new story anyway. The Fiction Editor will tell you the dangers of different initia. If you start with character, you should check to see whether you ever developed an engaging plot, for instance.
